page.title: 08EDUCATION-FALLING ROLLS
page.content: The second problem involes falling pupil numbers, and is one which is common to most L.E.A.'s. The retention of selection at 11+ ensures full capac- ity at the grammar schools. Many parents whose children fail 11+ send them to areas outside Lancaster where comprehensive schools are available, mainly Morecambe Carnforth, and Garstang. So the problem of falling rolls is greatly exacerbated by the selective system. In Lancaster two of the three secondary moderns have been severely affected. The Castle secondary school purpose built as a 6 form entry comprehensive,will have about 60 new pupiles in September 1985,or one third of it's potential intake. Proposals this year to merge Castle and Greaves school on a new site were vetoed by Sir Keith Joseph (Minister for Ed. & Sc).
